awd_titl_txt: Male Working Class Culture in France and the United States
awd_abstract_narration: This project analyzes French and American working class                    cultures by drawing on 200 in-depth interviews conducted with                   randomly sampled white and African-American working class men                   living the New York suburbs and with white and French Algerian                  working class men living in the Paris suburbs.  It examines the                 criteria that these men use to define, and to discriminate                      between, worthy and less worthy persons.  Drawing on available                  data on French and American upper-middle class cultures, the                    study will explore issues such as the extent of working class                   resistance to upper-middle class culture, the decline of working                class cultural distinctiveness, and cultural difference between                 majority and minority working class men.                                             This study will make a significant contribution to the                     understanding of national cultures and of racial differences                    within these cultures.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences
